Posts.Content: Hi Wendy I'm 7 weeks post surgery and had something similar.. My bcn said mine was scar tissue and quite normal and that it would soft in time. Bio oil doesn't make much difference to scar tissue internally but massage will. I eventually had 1500ml of fluid drained off, seeing my nurse twice a week for 4 weeks! Think that's all done as there hasn't bee any fluid build up for 10 days now.üò∑
Posts.Title: Mastectomy swelling, scar tissue?

Posts.Content: Good morning all. I've been following this conversation and thinking just how lucky I've been since my diagnosis back in June, just 2 weeks before we went on holiday. I had my surgery in August and since then we've done lots of stuff. 3 weeks after surgery was my birthday don't we had a day in London. The week before I started my chemo and to celberate our wedding anniversary we had 4 days in Paris. we go to the theatre and cinem as often as possible. This isn't just about me, hubbie is living with too. Over the last 10 years we've had sick and ageing parents (long distance) that took up most of our weekends and we were both working full time. So when all this happened I was determined I wasn't going to go into a decline and as a result, I do feel OK most days but am very aware of my limitations. This little bugger affects us all very differently and I know I've been a lot luckier than some of my poor cyber friends. I'm now looking forward to the end of chemo (1 more to go) and all the things we've got planned for the summer. And we probably would'nt have planned some of them had it not been for my BC.
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: How I agree with you. For the first time I can do make up Properly and feel confident in how I look. Hubbie is delighed.
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: It might be cold and windy out there but it is very sunny. Just picked out my new kitchen. Even better, I've had scrambled egg and toast for lunch - tasted every last forkful. Life is starting to look much better.

Posts.Content: George, do you know just how much some of love you? Going to Tesco's tomorrow to replace my bottle of Bailey's while I can still taste it, wouldn't it be great if this was available on the NHS?

When I got there, the radiographer had me listed for a mammo as well. First I'd heard of it. Than she couldn't get a clear image. When she finally did the scan, I'd got a large seroma which she partially drained. Gave me the all clear there and then, but for 10-15 minutes I was imagining all sorts of things.
Posts.Title: IS THIS YOU?

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, by the sound of it we had mastectomies at about the same time. The difference being, I had my lymph nodes removed at the same time. I started driving 3 weeks after surgery and, thanks to the exercises my bcn gave me, have almost full movement in my arm. Still not doing any heavy lifting. Your bcn will guide you through it, but remember there is no set pattern to recovery. Good luck.

OK so christmas will be a little different this year but there's a weekend with my nearest and dearest to look forward very soon after. Most important of all, I have the best possible prognosis. I'm a lucky lady.

Posts.Content: You poor thing! We've all cried over the silliest things. I didn't shred a single tear during tests, results and surgery. 2 weeks after surgery my surgeon said she was happy for us to,go,to,Paris. at the time my bcn was still draining fluid off the wound and wouldn't discharge me for a bra fitting which meant I had to use my softie. I cried all the way home from the hospital. I starated chemo in October and 2 weeks later my hair started to come out. Another bawl. Sometimes we can deal with the "big" things and it's the little things that reduce us to tears. ¬†there will alwsys be someone on this site to give you a virtual hug. Please ¬†don't try and do this alone.

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, life does change and this is something we have total control over. We'd got into the the habit of going to the cinema once a week. We still do that but not on the day of my chemo or the 2 days after. My oncologist told me that my biggest problem was not other people's infections but my own body trying to deal with them. We sometimes go to the pub for a meal after the film. I've seen something on at the local theatre that we both want to see, so I'm looking at the dates for that, I also go to a food tasting panEl that I've been doing for a year, but that is when I feel up to it and it fits in with everythin else. The most important things are ¬†to listen to your body and do what's good for you and your important other half.

Posts.Content: Hi Jan, they mention that particular side effect do they? It is quite common. I had something similar but after my chemo had finished. I lived on tomato soup for weeks. Soft scrambled eggs helped a lot. Anything that I could just swallow was fine. Sometimes for a change I bought small pots of custard, yogurt was ok too. It will pass but do make sure what you manage is good and nutritious. I was told to ditch the low fat stuff, have full fat milk, butter and yogurt. You might find ice cream tempting too. Good luck

Posts.Content: Hi. I've finished all my chemo and carried on as normal all the way through. My onco told me not to hibernate but be sensible. Obviously stay away from people with infection where you can and no changing babies nappies. I used disposal gloves when handling rawmeat and if eating out just go to places you trust and that cook to order. We went out as normal and I only had a few days when I didn't go shopping and they were the days when I wasn't feeling well. Just be sensible and trust your own instincts. Your own body will tell you what it can/doesn't want to do.

Posts.Content: First important piece of advice - listen to your surgeon, sounds like he is giving you the same advice I had from mine. Your wound side will nd to recover and that Cantake time . Also if you then need to have RT the implant can go hard and will need to b removed. I was big busted too before my mx (40dd) and my surgeon said that there was no way she could match them. I had a prothesis to start with (think of it s a bridging loan). Now two years post treatment I've got my new boobs (38c) nd they're lovely. I've got a prothesis nipple on the reconstructed side. I see my surgeon in 3 weeks for a check up. The prothesis fitter at the hospital has offered to make an air filled on to round off the shape for me. If you'd like a picture of my nipple let me know . The best bit is tht I don't have to wear huge bra and can evn go without¬†

Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: Hi and (sadly) welcome. I had my surgery a year ago ¬†and waited 9 weeks for my appt with the bra fitter, so for you the wait is about right. You need to be fully healed first. I assume that you have a "softie ". If not, speak to your bcn. I'm big busted too and my nurse to,d me that a roll of rice would add weight and it works. It's only for a shor the time so try not to let it get you down too much. Your bodynis still recovering from a major trauma so get lots of rest. I wore loose fitting tops in the beginning which helped to disguise my lopsidedness. Find a soft bra that fits well, I found it helped to wear one 24/7 for a while. You'll get lots of support here, you're not on your own.

Posts.Title: Work with head scarf on !

Posts.Content: Oh Jessie, you poor girl. Finding the lump is bad enough but too be treated so unkindly and unfeelingly makes it 100 times worse. If this helps, here's how it went for me. My lump was found by a routine mammo. I had a follow up appt 2 weeks later which consisted of a 2nd mammo, an ultra sound and core biopsy all within 90 minutes. The following week a saw my lovely surgeon who gave me the initial results. At that time she was talking straightforward lumpectomy but needs me to have an MRI to be sure she had enough clear margin. Sadly for me it wasn't to be and when I saw her a week later she confirmed I would need a full mastectomy. At all of my appointments I had access to a breast nurse if I wanted it. And every time I've seen my lovely surgeon there has been a bc nurse there. I'm now 6weeks post op and have nothing but praise for the team looking after me. At every stage they have made sure that I've had all the info I might need. You will also loads of lovely people on this forum who've been through this and will offer advice not found in any book. I hope this helps, this is the one time of your life when you really need too make as big a fuss as you need to, it's yupour body. Do let us know how you get on. Lots of hugs,üòç

Posts.Content: Hi there, I had this done between March and June and this week had my final surgery to reconstruct my left breast (had my mastectomy in August 2014). ¬†The operation to fit the temporary implant took about an hour and I was discharged the same day. I then saw my surgeon most weeks from 20 April until the end of May when we decided that we'd got the size we wanted. Be warned the tissue expander looks nothing like the finished item. It can feel a it uncomfortable for a day or two but it is not painful. I had my permanent implant and the other breast reduced on Monday and neither looks like a breast at the moment but my surgeon said she was happy with it and I trust her completely. Good luck I am sore and bruised at the moment but pain free¬†

Posts.Content: I remember that well. It sounds like. A seroma. When something is removed and leaves a void, nature fills it up. In this case with fluid. My breast nurse drained almost 2 litres over 5 weeks after my surgery. It's not much fun but necessary. Some oncologists won't start chemotherapy until it's all gone. I've just had breast reduction surgery on my remaining breast and according to the breast nurse yesterday iv got a small seroma that doesn't need draining and will clear up by itself over the next few weeks.
